resources.string: This service looks at the information reported to TalkBack and checks it for Accessibility issues. If issues are found, the offending views are highlighted in a thin border.
Attest desktop client still highlighting, stop highlighting to interact with app.

In the Android Accessibility world there are multiple ways of providing alternate text for a view. The content description attribute is the most basic. It attaches a description to a view, ImageView, or other focusable object, that otherwise has no string content. When writing content descriptions, be sure to consider the basic ARIA name, role, state, and value. Remember that TalkBack and the Android framework attempt to figure some of this out for you based on the type of object you are using. That being said, it is important to test your application with TalkBack to ensure everything is announced properly.

In the Android Accessibility world there are multiple ways of providing alternate text for a view. The content description attribute is the most basic. It attaches a description to a view, ImageView, or other focusable object, that otherwise has no string content. When writing content descriptions, be sure to consider the basic Accessible Rich Internet Application name, role, state, and value. Remember that TalkBack and the Android framework attempt to figure some of this out for you based on the type of object you are using. That being said, it is important to test your application with TalkBack to ensure everything is announced properly.
This image has a null content description. As a result, the user can\'t focus on it using TalkBack; this makes it impossible for the user to obtain information about the image.

This image has a blank string as a content description. Such a description allows the user to focus on the image using TalkBack, but the description is a default image number and the information that the image is \"unlabeled,\" which is entirely unhelpful. An empty content description occurs when it is hardcoded in xml as a blank string, which is a string made up of whitespace characters. If it is hardcoded as an empty string or assigned as an empty or lank string in a separate strings.xml file, the ImageView behaves as if it had a null content description

Content descriptions should be used in order to provide information desribing a focusable object, such as an ImageView. Content descriptions should not be used for background images, decorative borders, or other things that are not pertinent to the information being conveyed through your app or website.
This image\'s content description exactly duplicates the visual label and thus provides no new information to a TalkBack user.

Fixing this accessibility issue is simple. All you need to do is add a content description to objects that display pertinent information or perform a function such as non-decorative ImageViews, Switches, Buttons, other views, etc. These content descriptions should be concise, but as descriptive as possible in order to provide a TalkBack user with the information necessary to interpret the object. The first two issues, null and empty content descriptions, can be fixed in this way. To fix the third issue, duplicated information, be sure to think about the best combination of content description and visual label so as not to be redundant, but still provide necessary information for a TalkBack user.
Look at these drawings of animals!
Here is a drawing of a fish.
Here is a drawing of a dog.
Here is a drawing of a cat.

The first image in this example has duplicated information in the label and content description. The TalkBack user does not gain anything from having the same information read out twice and is instead bogged down by redundant informaiton. This does not map to any specific WCag rule, but is generally poor practice.

The first image in this example has duplicated information in the label and content description. The TalkBack user does not gain anything from having the same information read out twice and is instead bogged down by redundant informaiton. This does not map to any specific W Cag rule, but is generally poor practice.

The second image in this example has a content description, so it is focusable using TalkBack. However, the content description is a blank string, so TalkBack describes the image by its image number and states that the image is unlabeled. Such information is not useful to the user. Unfortunately, Android Studio does not flag this as an accessibility warning. This violates WCag 1.1.1 which you can learn more about by following the link below.

The second image in this example has a content description, so it is focusable using TalkBack. However, the content description is a blank string, so TalkBack describes the image by its image number and states that the image is unlabeled. Such information is not useful to the user. Unfortunately, Android Studio does not flag this as an accessibility warning. This violates the W Cag 1.1.1 which you can learn more about by following the link below.

The third image in this example is not focusable because it has a null content description. A TalkBack user would not even know that this image exists. Android Studio flags this as an accessibility warning, as long as the check is enabled. This violates WCag 2.4.3, which you cna learn more about by following the link below.

The third image in this example is not focusable because it has a null content description. A TalkBack user would not even know that this image exists. Android Studio flags this as an accessibility warning, as long as the check is enabled. This violates the W Cag 2.4.3, which you cna learn more about by following the link below.
Look at these drawings of animals!
These two images are now accessible to a TalkBack user because they both have a content description.
Here is a drawing of a fish.
Here is a drawing of a dog.
Here is a drawing of a cat.
By providing concise, descriptive content descriptions that provide different information than the labels to these ImageViews, you can now use TalkBack to gain information about these objects.
To simulate what its like to rely on TalkBack to navigate a mobile application first turn on TalkBack in Settings > Accessibility > TalkBack.

Then, click on the icon in this application\'s toolbar. It looks exactly like the image above. Clicking that icon will mask the page and simulate what it is like to rely on TalkBack to navigate through the screen.

TalkBack is a pre-installed screen reader and accessibility tool on Android devices. When activated it uses cues such as audible announcements, vibrations, and sounds to provide users with the information they need to navigate the screen.\n\nTalkBack works with Explore by Touch, which is a system feature, to enable users to touch the screen and hear what is selected, along with other valuable information such as which actions are available or which other screen elements are associated with the selected element.
TalkBack can be turned on by going into Settings > Accessibility > TalkBack and toggle the switch to turn it on (you will need to accept some conditions first).

Talkback has a large number of shortcuts to enable expert users to utilize the application efficiently. The shortcuts may be confusing to a novice user. Android has a TalkBack tutorial built in, but in the interest of time the most common shortcuts are listed below.
Swipe down or right: This scrolls \"down\" through views that can be highlighted.
Swipe up or left: This scrolls \"up\" through views that can be highlighted.
Double tap: This clicks on a highlighted view. If clicking triggers an action for the current view, it will be triggered by this gesture when TalkBack is activated.
Two fingered scroll: This scrolls a scrollable screen, including nested scrolls such as lists.
If you need to scroll down the page to view all its content when TalkBack is activated, don\'t forget to scroll with two fingers instead of one!
Is TalkBack turned on? If not, see the \"About\" tab for instructions on how to do so. Once that\'s done, come back to this page and tap this TextView.
Swipe right or down until you reach the EditText below.
Now follow the prompts that TalkBack gives you and double tap to edit.

Continue swiping right or down until you reach this view. Now try going backwards. Swipe left or up to scroll up through the views on the page. Continue this pattern until you get the hang of scrolling through views.
Tap and hold on the screen. Now move your finger around to explore the views this way. Once you lift your finger, whichever view was under it last will be highlighted.
Continue to explore the screen by touch, but at the end highlight the \"Advanced\" tab below.

Once a clickable view, such as the EditText above, is highlighted, double tap the screen anywhere to perform a click action. Navigate to the EditText above (there are multiple ways to do this!) and double tap to edit it.

Click on this icon in the upper right hand corner to simulate what it\'s like to rely on TalkBack to navigate through the screen. See if you can navigate to different views and screens using your new TalkBack skills.
Now that you know the basics of how to navigate the screen using TalkBack, you can learn about some more handy gestures and shortcuts that can aid TalkBack users.

You can use the default gestures that are programmed into the pre-installed TalkBack or you can set your own by navigating to Settings > Accessibility > TalkBack > Settings > Touch Exploration > Manage gestures. This menu also hosts the entire set of default gestures that TalkBack recognizes.
Up then down: Highlight first element on the screen
Down then up: Highlight the last element on the screen
Right then left: Scroll forward, if the view is longer than one page
Left then right: Scroll backwards, if the view is longer than one page
Reference these demos when you need clarity on a rule violation.
Reference these demos when you need clarity on a rule violation.
